info.game_comments: J! round & 15 clues of DJ! round only

(1, 1).clue: As a teenager, she cut her hair, dressed in boyish clothes & called herself William Cather

(2, 1).clue: From the Old Norse word for a roof beam, it's a craft of beams lashed together

(3, 1).clue: Facing the altar, it's the side of the church where the relatives & friends of the bride sit

(4, 1).clue: At the Highland Games, all Scots who want to toss the caber or the weight must wear this

(5, 1).clue: This Tijuana Brass leader now markets a women's perfume called "Listen"

(6, 1).clue: A really dumb person or the toy Tommy Smothers plays with on his "Comedy Hour"

(1, 2).clue: Playwright Oliver Goldsmith may have written some of the rhymes attributed to this old woman

(2, 2).clue: A London cab drove for 70 days from Buckingham Palace to this Australian opera house

(3, 2).clue: (AUDIO DAILY DOUBLE)  Title of the following in which Marilyn McCoo addressed her then-fiance, Billy Davis Jr.: " and love won't carry metill you marry me Bill / Bill I love you so / I always will / And in your voice I hear a choir of carousels..."

(4, 2).clue: Persia may have been the birthplace of this equestrian team sport

(5, 2).clue: In the U.S., no company can now sell a 3-wheeled "ATV", which stands for this

(6, 2).clue: In a certain Coleridge poem it precedes "everywhere, nor any drop to drink"

(1, 3).clue: Shortly before his death, Washington Irving completed a 5-volume biography of this president

(2, 3).clue: Like the Wrights, the Dodge Brothers began their career in transportation making these

(3, 3).clue: She & Rep. Nicholas Longworth had a White House wedding in 1906

(4, 3).clue: Though Hartford isn't a seaport, its pro hockey team is called this

(5, 3).clue: Saying "Nikon has the perfect camera for both", its ads include photos of Einstein & this Stooge

(6, 3).clue: It's the capital of America Samoa

(1, 4).clue: Though he was born in Prague, Franz Kafka wrote his novels in this language

(2, 4).clue: The events at the '88 Summer Olympics ran from A to Y, archery to this

(3, 4).clue: At the end of a traditional Jewish marriage ceremony the groom smashes one of these with his foot

(4, 4).clue: They lost back to back Super Bowls in 1987-1988

(5, 4).clue: In America, wine made by the Charmat Process can be labeled champagne, but in France it must be labeled this

(1, 5).clue: After this philosopher sired Heloise's illegitimate child, her uncle had him emasculated

(2, 5).clue: Name of the high speed passenger trains running between Washington, D.C. & NYC

(3, 5).clue: During the bride & groom's 1st dance, the bride's father should dance 1st with this person

(4, 5).clue: Sizzling the pits, lollipop & digging lips are terms in this sport, whether on the court or on the beach

(5, 5).clue: The highest price paid for any Chinese ceramic work of art was for a 15th c. vase from this dynasty

(1, 1).clue: In 1915 he chartered a "peace ship" & built his millionth car; he was busy

(2, 1).clue: This bottled bean extract must contain at least 35% alcohol

(3, 1).clue: War broke out on Sept. 22, 1980 when fighter bombers from this nation attacked 10 Iranian airfields

(4, 1).clue: At the end of their story, Psyche & this cute Roman love god lived happily ever after

(1, 2).clue: In 1894 while the gov't was trying to break the Pullman strike, Congress made this a national holiday

(2, 2).clue: Served by the Indians at the 1st Thanksgiving, this food explodes when cooked

(3, 2).clue: The building of Egypt's Aswan High Dam in the 1960s was financed by loans from this country

(1, 3).clue: On July 26, 1775 Congress established this service & put Ben Franklin in charge

(2, 3).clue: An important product of Hawaii which Luther Burbank called "the perfect nut"

(3, 3).clue: Of all the Arab countries, this one has the highest percentage of Christians, about 40%

(2, 4).clue: Also called the "butter bean", it was 1st cultivated by Peruvian Indians

(3, 4).clue: In 1917 Britain issued the Balfour Declaration which called for the creation of this

(1, 5).clue: John Adams & Jefferson both died on the July 4th that marked this anniversary of our independence

(3, 5).clue: In 1941 Syria gained its independence from this European country
